title: Common Verbs (Kano, Meno, Thelo).
reading_greek:
ΚΕΦΑΛΑΙΟ 8 | Ο αόριστος

8.1 Η μορφή του αόριστου

8.1.1 Αρκετές φορές, τα ρήματα αλλάζουν λίγο όταν περνάει ο χρόνος. Αυτό συμβαίνει και με τα ρήματα που έχουμε ήδη δει. Ας δούμε τα ρήματα: κάνω, μένω, θέλω.

• κάνω (imperfective stem: κάν-) → έκανα
• μένω (imperfective stem: μεν-) → έμεινα
• θέλω (imperfective stem: θελ-) → ήθελα

8.1.3 Κανονικά ρήματα

Ας δούμε μερικά ακόμα ρήματα που ακολουθούν απλούς κανόνες:

• γράφω → έγραψα
• πίνω → ήπια
• βλέπω → είδα
• παίζω → έπαιξα
• ακούω → άκουσα
reading_english:
CHAPTER 8 | The Aorist

8.1 The Form of the Aorist

8.1.1 Several times, verbs change a little when time passes. This also happens with the verbs we have already seen. Let's look at the verbs: kano, meno, thelo.

• kano (imperfective stem: kan-) → ekana
• meno (imperfective stem: men-) → emina
• thelo (imperfective stem: thel-) → ithela

8.1.3 Regular Verbs

Let's see some more verbs that follow simple rules:

• grapho → egapsa
• pino → ipia
• vlevo → ida
• pezo → epaiksa
• akouo → akousa
audio_script:
Hello! Let's continue our journey into Modern Greek grammar. Today, we're focusing on some very common verbs and how they change, specifically when we talk about past actions in the aorist tense. This is covered in Chapter 8 of our textbook.

In Modern Greek, verbs often change slightly to indicate past actions. We're going to look at three essential verbs: 'kano' (to do/make), 'meno' (to stay/live), and 'thelo' (to want). These are fundamental for everyday communication.

Let's start with 'kano'. The imperfective stem, which we use for present actions, is 'kan-'. When we put it into the aorist tense, it becomes 'ekana'. So, 'I did' or 'I made' is 'ekana'.

Next, we have 'meno'. Its imperfective stem is 'men-'. In the aorist, it transforms into 'emina'. This means 'I stayed' or 'I lived'.

And finally, 'thelo'. The imperfective stem here is 'thel-'. For the aorist, it changes to 'ithela', meaning 'I wanted'.

Now, let's look at some other verbs that follow a similar pattern, which the textbook calls 'regular verbs' in section 8.1.3. These are also very common!

We have 'grapho', which means 'to write'. In the aorist, it becomes 'egrapsa' - 'I wrote'.

Then there's 'pino', meaning 'to drink'. The aorist form is 'ipia' - 'I drank'.

'Vlevo' means 'to see'. Its aorist form is 'ida' - 'I saw'.

'Paizo', meaning 'to play', becomes 'epaipsa' in the aorist - 'I played'.

And finally, 'akouo', which means 'to hear' or 'to listen'. In the aorist, it's 'akousa' - 'I heard' or 'I listened'.

Remember, mastering these verb forms is crucial. Keep practicing them! We'll explore more verb tenses and forms in upcoming lessons. Thank you!
